questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman with no significant medical history reports a 3-week history of persistent pain in her right anterior hip and groin. She runs regularly for exercise, up to 20 miles per week, but has had to discontinue her exercise regimen because of the pain. The pain is constant and dull and is exacerbated by walking, pivoting, and prolonged sitting. The patient also describes an intermittent clicking sensation when she walks.
Her vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, right-sided groin pain is elicited by a combined maneuver of 90 degrees of flexion, adduction, and internal rotation of the right hip. Other maneuvers of the right hip do not produce pain, and there is full range of motion. Plain radiography of the right hip is unremarkable.
Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Greater trochanteric pain syndrome (formerly referred to as trochanteric bursitis) is due to repetitive activity or trauma and typically causes lateral hip pain aggravated by direct pressure over the greater trochanter. Most cases presenting clinically as greater trochanteric pain syndrome actually represent tendinosis of the gluteus medius and/or gluteus minimus tendons.

B) INCORRECT:

Iliotibial band syndrome is a common cause of lateral hip and knee symptoms characterized by sharp or burning pain that is exacerbated by activity, typically distance running.

C) INCORRECT:

Groin pain from hip osteoarthritis usually occurs in patients over 40 years of age, and radiography is usually abnormal when osteoarthritis is advanced enough to cause hip pain.

D) CORRECT:

A labral tear should be suspected in a young athletic patient with positional anterior groin pain. Plain radiographic films can appear normal or may show evidence of hip dysplasia, which can predispose patients to labral tears. Femoroacetabular impingement is another common mechanical condition that predisposes patients to labral tears, and the physical exam maneuver described (hip impingement test) is also positive in femoroacetabular impingement.

Ultrasound or magnetic resonance imaging can often suggest the presence of an acetabular labral tear, but magnetic resonance arthrography with administration of intra-articular gadolinium is the preferred imaging technique for identifying labral pathologic findings. Acetabular labral tears may predispose patients to early hip osteoarthritis.

Typically, conservative management, including relative rest, antiinflammatory medications, and focused physical therapy, is initially recommended. If this does not control symptoms or if functional limitations persist, a glucocorticoid injection may be considered, or a referral may be made to an orthopedist for possible arthroscopic debridement and surgical repair of associated structural problems.

Key learning point: In an otherwise healthy, athletic patient and in the absence of trauma, a labral tear can manifest as subacute anterior groin pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Occult hip fracture (nondisplaced fracture of the femoral neck) should be suspected in patients with severe anterolateral hip tenderness, severe pain with even partial weight-bearing, and intolerance to passive rotation of the hip.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman reports several weeks of pain in her right hip. She typically runs 3 to 5 miles daily but has stopped her running routine because of worsening pain during the past 3 weeks. She recalls no particular trauma. Her pain is localized mainly over the anterior groin. The pain is exacerbated by walking, and pivoting to the right produces pain and a catching sensation in the hip.
Examination of the right hip reveals mild limitation in internal rotation but an otherwise full range of motion. The patient has pain at the extreme of flexion. Simultaneous internal rotation and adduction of the flexed hip causes discomfort. Resisted hip flexion does not cause pain, and there is no tenderness over the lateral aspect of the hip girdle. Her straight-leg raise is normal. Examination of the left hip is normal.
A radiograph of the pelvis reveals mild dysplasia of the right hip but is otherwise normal.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s pain?

choices.text: Referred pain related to lumbar radiculopathy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Greater trochanteric pain syndrome (formerly referred to as trochanteric bursitis) causes pain and tenderness over the lateral hip.

B) CORRECT:

The labrum is the fibrocartilaginous tissue attached to the rim of the acetabulum. Labrum tears, which are common in athletes, can happen after twisting or pivoting injuries — or insidiously without a clear history of trauma. Typical examination findings include pain upon maximum flexion and upon simultaneous internal rotation and adduction of the flexed hip.

In the majority of young patients with labrum tears, a radiograph reveals osseous abnormalities, such as acetabular dysplasia or diminished offset at the femoral head-neck junction. Those risk factors for labrum tear can provide a clue to the diagnosis. A magnetic resonance arthrogram is the preferred imaging modality for detecting labrum tears.

Key learning point: Hip pain in a young athlete with femoroacetabular dysplasia is most likely to be attributable to a labrum tear.

C) INCORRECT:

Iliopsoas tendinopathy is another cause of anterior hip pain in runners. Typical examination findings include pain upon resisted hip flexion. Bone radiographs are normal.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteitis pubis is an inflammation of the pubic symphysis that typically causes pain in the region of the symphysis and in the lower abdomen. Although this condition can also, on rare occasions, manifest with groin pain, it would not be expected to cause the abnormal hip examination seen in this case; the most common examination finding is pain with pressure on the symphysis. Radiographs can show chronic changes such as widening and cysts but may be normal in early stages.

E) INCORRECT:

Referred pain related to lumbar radiculopathy is unlikely; the patient has no back pain, and she has discomfort with maneuvers involving hip range of motion.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl is brought in to establish care. She is accompanied by her mother and grandmother, who report that she has been healthy and developing normally. Their only concern today is intoeing, which they have noticed since the girl started walking at age 14 months. The mother also had intoeing as a child and was fitted for braces. She reports that her daughter keeps up with the other kids at school and loves to run and climb. During the interview, the child sits on the floor in a “W” position, looking at a book, with her thighs internally rotated and her lower legs externally rotated.
On examination, all of the child’s growth parameters are at the 50th percentile. She has normal tone in her upper and lower extremities and 5/5 strength in all limbs. Her heel bisector line goes through the second toe on both feet, and her thigh-foot angle is about 5 degrees bilaterally. When she walks in the office, intoeing is evident bilaterally, and when she runs, she exhibits an eggbeater running pattern (medial rotation of the thighs and outward rotation of the feet).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Order radiographs of the pelvis and hips
Order radiographs of the lower extremities
Reassure the mother that the intoeing is likely to resolve on its own

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Orthopedic referral is warranted when intoeing is unilateral, when there is concern about muscle tone or strength, or when symptoms progress, all of which can signal a more serious pathology.

B) INCORRECT:

Given that the most common causes of intoeing can be diagnosed clinically, radiographs are not typically necessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Given that the most common causes of intoeing can be diagnosed clinically, radiographs are not typically necessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Historically, increased femoral anteversion was treated with orthotics, splinting, and bracing, but none of these interventions has been found to be effective.

E) CORRECT:

Intoeing is a common gait disturbance in which the toes point toward the midline. Although it is a very common reason for referral to orthopedic surgery, most children with this rotational variation improve on their own without intervention. The most common causes of intoeing in children are metatarsus adductus, internal tibial torsion, and increased femoral anteversion.

In this patient, the physical examination findings are consistent with increased femoral anteversion, which causes increased internal rotation of the hip and decreased external rotation of the hip. It is the most common cause of intoeing after age 3. Affected children often sit in a “W” position and exhibit an eggbeater running pattern (medial rotation of the thighs and outward rotation of the feet). Although there has been some speculation that limiting “W” sitting may prevent or worsen femoral anteversion, there is no evidence for either effect. Femoral anteversion is more common in girls than boys, tends to run in families, and usually resolves spontaneously by age 11. Historically, it was treated with orthotics, splinting, and bracing, but none of these interventions has been found to be effective. Observation and parental reassurance are now the preferred management.

Metatarsus adductus is the most common cause of intoeing in infants and is characterized by a heel bisector line that goes through the more lateral toes, giving the foot a “C” shape. It usually resolves spontaneously by age 2 and requires intervention only if it is unilateral.

Internal tibial torsion is the most common cause of intoeing among toddlers and is typically bilateral. When the thigh-foot angle is measured in children with this condition, the line of the heel points toward the midline. Internal tibial torsion usually resolves spontaneously by age 5 but may require surgery in children older than age 8. This patient has a normal heel-bisector line and heel-thigh angle, which rules out both metatarsus adductus and internal tibial torsion.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for a 6-year-old child with bilateral intoeing whose physical examination reveals increased femoral anteversion is parental reassurance.
